K is forâ€¦ KXM

Photo borrowed from unsungmelody.com, credit: Sebastien Paquet[1].

Yeah yeah, supergroups. Itâ€™s a mixed bag of hot weasels, really.

You do get a few that fit the clichÃ©, where theyâ€™re a big disappointment and nothing quite works like it should because of all the egos getting in the way, but I struggle to think of any at the moment.

Then you get the â€œmehâ€ ones where it all sort of works, but doesnâ€™t exactly set the world on fire (Chickenfoot, Audioslave, Zwan, Hellyeah, The Winery Dogs), you get the ones where it all works really well (Velvet Revolver, Brides of Destruction, Sons of Apollo, The Dead Daisies, Frost*, Alter Bridge, The Damned Things, Flying Colors) and then you get a couple of really rare ones where they are in fact the best thing thatâ€™s ever happened (David Lee Roth band[2], Mr. Big).

Well, KXM are really very good indeed[3]. Drummer Ray Luzier brings the â€œKâ€ from KoRn, guitarist and friend of the show, the omnipresent hardest-working-rock-star-in-America George Lynch brings the â€œMâ€ from Lynch Mob; and the â€œXâ€ is lovingly provided by Doug Pinnick â€“ bassist, vocalist and creative powerhouse behind Kingâ€™s X.

With the â€œsuperâ€ credentials established and out of the way, and an average age (at time of writing) of 65.667, these are clearly musicians who have been round the block a few times, so does it work when they get together? Is there chemistry? This is, after all, what a band must have in order to generate music that works, and the lack of which can lead to supergroups ailing, failing and flailing.

It sure does. Doug has such a distinctive sound both on bass and vocals that there was a potential danger of this sounding like a Kingâ€™s X knock-off, but with Lynch on guitar that was never going to happen. Iâ€™ve said a thousand times that George has such a distinctive style, you can tell itâ€™s him with one note. How many rock guitarists can you really say that about?[4] Ray is absolutely excellent on drums, also. Iâ€™ve never really dug KoRn, but his playing on the KXM records is tight and fresh, leaving plenty of room for George to sprinkle his Lynchy noodles.

Best power trio since Primus? Controversialâ€¦ but perhapsâ€¦ yes?

Get on it.

Clive recommends:

All three records are superb. I think for the best balance, as a showcase of what they do, you would be best served starting with 2017â€™s Scatterbrain, but please do hoover them all up if you dig it.
